Comments_List: I don't think I could even put into words everything I learned about my field, about method, and about academia from this class.
I learned how to work across disciplines-- particularly, how to merge literary and historical methods.
The future of Black Studies this is the first course in AFAM that truly revolutionized my thinking.

Having so many different guest speakers in the class was a huge strength to me. I enjoyed the ability to ask questions directly to the authors we read, and to hear so many different opinions about graduate school and our future careers.
The strengths of this course were the quality of discussion, the instructor's knowledge of material, and the quality of the syllabus. No areas of improvement.
I wish every graduate student could take a class with Hazel Carby. Actually, I wish they were required to.
Yes. I believe the discussions across disciplines was incredibly valuable.
